awd_titl_txt: Multi-scale Dynamics of White-nose Syndrome in North America
awd_abstract_narration:
Forecasting the spread of epidemics or invasive organisms at continental scales is complicated by processes acting at multiple scales on varied landscapes. Yet such forecasts are crucial for managing and halting epidemic spread. This project uses computational tools from mathematics, computer science, epidemiology and ecology to understand and predict the spread of a devastating disease of cave-dwelling bats, white-nose syndrome, which is caused by the soil fungus, Pseudogymnoascus destructans. This project addresses two specific problems. First, it seeks to identify the corridors along which white-nose syndrome is likely to spread and the locations most at risk, using the spatial pattern of past spread and an approach called network analysis. New methods will be used that will speed up computations, turning the computer model into a more useful tool in management and control. Second, the local, random processes that affect individual caves will be linked to the process of spread at regional to continental scales. This multi-scale linkage will be the first to use a simulation modeling method, called the equation-free approach, to estimating epidemics when data are limited, which is most of the time in such circumstances. The combining of these two approaches will provide a more accurate understanding how white-nose syndrome has spread already and how it is likely to spread in the future.

The economic benefit that bats provide to agriculture in the United States by eating insects has been estimated to be $4-50 billion each year. This project will contribute tools for controlling the spread of white-nose and the resulting losses to agriculture, as well as the serious impacts it has on the bats themselves. It is expected that the approaches and tools developed in this project for white-nose syndrome could also be applied to other wildlife diseases, as well as for the regional and continental spread of human pathogens. The scientists involved will communicate their practical findings directly to the land and natural resources managers and to the public. The project will also have educational benefits through the transfer of skills from the field of mathematics to ecology and epidemiology. The project will also provide exciting research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Making informative predictions about patterns of disease spread is difficult during the early stages of an emerging epidemic. The rate of spread and locations at highest risk depend on interactions between the individual, population, and continental scales at the same time that basic knowledge about the pathogen is limited. This project developed models of the ongoing epidemic of white-nose syndrome in North American cave-dwelling bats that improved understanding of regional and continental-scale dynamics of this disease and resulted in novel applications of these models to outbreaks of Ebola in human populations.

The movement of infected individuals or movement of uninfected individuals into contaminated environments are two primary mechanisms leading to spatial dispersion of an emerging disease. Because these movements are rarely random, modeling disease spread as taking place on a spatial network can provide actionable forecasts and insight into transmission mechanisms and interventions. We used a flexible statistical model to study the spread of white-nose syndrome across North America, showing that the spread took place across the network of caves and mines in a way that depended on distance, cave/mine density (possible as a proxy for bat density), and the climate in different locations. We established that year-to-year differences in weather explained the sequence of infections and found support for a change in network structure as the disease became more widespread. We also developed a software library designed to simplify the hard-to-interpret network structures that result from large-scale spatial models.

During this project the largest recorded outbreak of Ebola took place in West Africa. The model developed for white-nose syndrome was applied to the West African Ebola outbreak in real-time, accurately capturing the relative risk of infection across the region and exploring this impacts of border closures on the observed dynamics. From this model we found that indirect estimates of movement based on cell-phones were not able to capture the spatial dynamics of this outbreak. This work led to collaboration with the Centers for Disease Control and the health agencies in the Democratic Republic of Congo on the 10th and 11th outbreaks in that country, including providing real-time risk maps to various agencies.

While the network model captures broad-scale spatial dynamics of white-nose syndrome, the devastating loss of bats happens in each hibernaculum (cave or mine). We built a multi-scale model of white nose syndrome that modeled bat mortality due to white-nose syndrome as a result of disease progression within hibernacula and spread between hibernacula. As with many wildlife diseases the information on animal movement, disease transmission, and disease severity were of varying quality, but by comparing model output to observed patterns in survival, infection prevalence, and spread among hibernacula we found support for frequency-dependent transmission, an important role of environmental transmission, and little impact of bat dispersal on metapopulation survival. These factors had been previously inferred at isolated scales, and our model provides an assessment of how the interactions and feedbacks between these scales impacts population dynamics of the impacted bat species and a framework for improving predictions as knowledge increases.

Overall our study improved understanding of the macro-scale dynamics of this important wildlife disease that is impacting mammal and insect communities in North America. We did this by building models with potential for application to other wildlife and zoonotic diseases. We also developed tools for simplifying networks to facilitate interpretation and control decisions based on network processes. The project resulted in 4 peer-reviewed papers, 1 preprint and 7 conference presentations. Three undergraduates researchers were supported, all of whom were co-authors on papers and have gone on to graduate/professional degrees. Two of these undergraduates were under-represented minorities and one was a Goldwater Scholar and a finalist for the Rhodes and Marshall scholarships. One postdoc was supported through the transition into a faculty position. We are finalizing the R software package that will make our network simplification techniques widely available and have future publications planned utilizing these methods.
